text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cooking shrimp on pink
Himalayan salt and i've seen this done
and I've heard about this being done but
I've never tried it and I wanted to so I
did so the first thing you have to do is
heat this in a really hot oven to get
the salt nice and hot I figured I would
use a cast-iron pan to transfer it into
the oven and I would also help hold the
heat alright I got this at a local store
the guy at the store said it's like 200
million years old and I said don't you
have anything fresher alright so we're
gonna put that in a 450 degree oven for
20 minutes in the meantime I prepped my
shrimp very simply a little bit of
vegetable oil actually I use grapeseed
oil a little bit of cayenne and by a
little I mean a lot and a little pinch
of a cumin
now this may come as a shock to you but
I'm not going to put any salt in here
since we're going to cook this on a
giant block of salt alright so that was
mixed up 20 minutes later my salt was
hot and here we go we are going to
simply place the shrimp directly onto
the salt and you can hear the sizzle
pretty cool so this is not really a
recipe as much as it is you know an
experiment and that's why I only bought
you know a small block here they come in
much larger pieces if you want alright
so I'm watching in here and just like if
you were frying shrimp I'm watching the
heat transfer up through the shrimp and
when it's almost halfway up maybe just
past a third of the way up where the
translucent flesh is turning sort of
white I gave him a flip that was about
three minutes on that side and I thought
it looked really cool in fact I didn't
think it was going to you know have any
kind of a crust to it or a or a seared
surface but it actually looks pretty
cool so I give it about three minutes on
that side I decided to flip it up on the
flat side here just to finish off the
last bit of cooking so this was like
seven to eight minutes altogether
and I decided they were done transferred
him to a plate where I had some
beautiful apple jicama slaw which I will
demo in a video and that was it shrimp
cooked on pink salt now for the taste
test what did it taste like so tasted
exactly like shrimp as you would expect
I like the texture very juicy but that's
because I think it was cooked fairly
gently it wasn't too salty it was
actually just right for salt content
I thought all in all I was happy now
what I do this on a regular basis is a
way to cook shrimp probably not but for
a dinner party maybe if you have four of
these blocks and everyone gets one and
gets to cook their own strip for an
appetizer
that would be kind of cool I think that
would be a neat idea
all right so after I did that I wanted
to experiment further I'd seen on
YouTube people actually putting the salt
right on a flame so I figured let's try
that out so I put it on medium heat they
say don't go too high or you'll actually
you know burn the salt on the bottom so
I put it on a medium flame I put six
shrimp on this diet instead of three and
you can see there it definitely was
cooking faster there definitely was a
higher temperature on the surface of the
salt now the problem was because there
was so much more liquid than when I did
the three this batch got a little salty
the more liquid on the surface the more
salt that's going to be dissolved and
the more salty your product will be and
you can see here one issue this is
clearly too small of a piece the juices
were running over the edge alright my
maid is going to be so mad at me I
tasted this batch it wasn't bad it was a
little too salty
Aarti was salty like potato chips salty
not inedible but a little over salted
and that concludes our experiment
cooking on a pink Himalayan salt
I sure pehoe p-- you liked that I had to
do one Himalayan joke anyway like I said
kind of a fun project for a dinner party
head over to food wishes comm for more
information and the ingredient amounts
you know both
and as always enjoy
